hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Rough enough. Easier to get lost than seen today.
I do street photography. Analog, not digital. Smuggled film, if you’re curious.
All these disturbances make good photos tricky. Crowds too skittish to stand still.
Still got what I needed. Not my best roll, but it’ll do.
Hard to move out there tonight. City feels even more off than usual.
I shoot street scenes. Strictly 35mm. Digital: too easy to track.
People sense the tension. Makes them freeze up. Not great for natural shots.
Even my usual photo spots are watched now. Risky to linger with a camera.
Had to be quick. Not much art in the shadows these days.
Oh, it’s rough, but honest. I take analog street photos, catching what the city covers up.
With the BCI all scrambled, folks walk like they’re trespassing in their own lives.
My usual film is harder to get past the new patrols. Worth it, though.
Saw a lineup of city workers arguing with technocrats—my camera loves a mess like that.
Missed the perfect shot. Tram sirens, panic, everyone scattered.
Still, managed some real moments—the city’s guard slips when the system’s twitchy.
Tough day, but it makes the hobby worthwhile. I’m into street photography—old-school, real film.
Caught the city’s pulse with all these BCI glitches. People reveal themselves when authority stumbles.
Snuck my Leica out by the depot. Patrols everywhere after the job-switch chaos.
Got tense quick. Saw a baker bossing engineers—never thought I’d shoot something like that.
Film’s scarce. Each frame’s got to count these days, with checkpoints sniffing everything.
Sometimes I risk more for photos than for stories—truth’s best uncut.
Pretty sure my BCI score tanked for it, but hell, it’s worth it.
More chaos, better photos. I do analog street photography—Leica, smuggled rolls, the works.
Sometimes feels like the city’s only honest when it’s breaking down.
Today, BCI meltdown meant security barely looked at my badge, but I saw people ditch routines for survival.
Spent an hour capturing folks re-learning how to queue, barter, argue—real civilization beneath the surface.
My father was BCI—schooled me in what to see and what to hide.
I document shifts no one else dares keep—especially as these Halden rumors turn people raw.
Almost lost a roll to a patrol when Identities glitched. Close call but worth it.
I don’t just shoot the city—I hoard its contradictions before they’re algorithmically erased.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still shooting film. Old habits die hard.
Analog hasn’t been banned yet. Not officially anyway.
The broken BCI made patrols unpredictable—lost a couple rolls to a random sweep.
City’s messier now, but that’s all I’ll say.
People notice the lens a lot more these days.
That’s right, analog’s still kicking, for now.
Film’s tricky to come by lately—supply lines fell apart after Halden.
Took some shots last week when labor assignments went haywire.
Security’s less organized, but more jumpy. Riskier to wander with a camera.
I stick to side streets and burnt-out platforms now.
Saw an old baker leading IT guys through garbage duty, had to burn the shots fast.
You heard right, analog’s my stubborn streak.
Nothing digital catches what gets missed by the algorithms.
With the BCI stuttering, half the city’s out of place—makes for raw photos.
I slipped through Sector 4 during that labor fiasco, film hidden in a sock.
Guards glanced at my score but barely tracked me—everyone’s out of their depth.
The chaos let me get shots I’ve never dared before.
Burned extra film. Feels like the only time truth gets through.
Absolutely. Still shooting analog, even if it’s stupid right now.
These days, film’s more precious than bread.
Recently, I was out as the BCI crashed—volunteers sweeping up, executives mopping floors.
Tension in every shot. You can see who’s lost, who’s bluffing.
The city’s noise dropped, even the trams stopped for a bit.
Almost got stopped by a security swap team—my score flashed, they froze, then let me go.
That edge, that feeling? It sharpens every frame.
Feels like I’m archiving secrets before they disappear.
Still got my Leica—beats any scanner for catching real life.
Dad said photographing chaos is dangerous, but necessary.
These days, I smuggle film inside sleeves, dodge AI eyes when I can.
With BCI falling apart, uniformed kids patrol like they’re lost on a field trip.
Shot a team of reassigned programmers arguing over a broom—best picture I’ve taken this year.
The city’s breaking character, letting its real face slip through cracks.
Sometimes, I feel like I’m preserving a world no one’s supposed to remember.
If I disappear, those photos are the story it couldn’t silence.
Feels like I’m both witness and culprit, every time I press the shutter.
